723399f.title: Manhattan: Spring Street - West Street
723399f.text:
353 and 351 Spring Street, at and adjoiing the N.E.
corner of Weat Street. The corner buflding store is occu-
pied by the Savannah Lunch and Rest. Roane Bros. occupy
No. 351. These structures, including No. 349 whch is
not shown were demolished in 1927. This photograph is
taken during work on the West Street sewer project, con-
ourrent with the Holland Tunnel boring.
May 3, 1924
Standnrd Photographic Service

Fiers 35 and 36 North River, West Street, west side, north of
and from Spring Street.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
The same, a view a 1ittle farther to the north. Demolition
work is beginning en Fier 35.
March 8, 1929.

724668f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Spring Street
724668f-a.text:
West Street, west side, north from Spring Street, showing Pier No 35,
North River.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

724668f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724664f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Spring Street
724664f-a.text:
West Street, north from and including Spring Street and Pier 35,
North River. The West Side Elevated Highway is under construction
from this point north to 23rd Street and Eleventh Avenue, it will
be opened in November.
The boy on horseback is supposed to be warning vehicles and ped-
estrians out of the way of the oncoming train.
June 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724664f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724669f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Spring Street
724669f-a.text:
West Street, west side, from Spring to Charlton Streets (Piers 36-37,
N.R.), showing city officials, led by Borough President Julius Miller,
making an inspection trip up the first section of the West Side
Elevated Highway from the southern end. The first section extends from
Canal Street (actually from the western end of Spring Street) to 23rd
Street. Ground was broken by Mayor Walker and Borough President
Miller on May 24, 1929; and the section will be formally opened on
November 13, 1930.
October 27, 1930.
International News Photos, Inc.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724669f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724683f-a.text:

The NIew Vork Central's Rew St. Nohn's Park Freight

She above photo shows eight tracks entering St. 'ohn's

723398f-a.title: Manhattan: Spring Street - West Street
723398f-a.text:
Demolition of 3b3-34V Spring Street, three six-story tenement houses
at and adjoining the N.E. corner of West Street.
October 25, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
723398f-a.folder: Spring Street & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724663f.title: Manhattan: West Street - Spring Street
724663f.text:
(1)
West Street, center and east side, north from and including
Spring Street (opposite Pier 35, North River).
September 27, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, nearly seven years later, not including Spring Street.
The Sobol filling station, which is only partly shown at the
right, occupies the site of the buildings at and adjoining
the north corner of Spring Street. The West Side Elevated
Highway was opened from this point to 23rd Street late in
1930; and the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal, from
Charlton to Clarkson Streets, is practically completed as
shown.
June 15, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724663f.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724666f-b.title: Manhattan: West Street - Spring Street
724666f-b.text:
(1)
West Street, at and adjoining the north corner of Spring Street,
opposite Pier 35, North River. The gasoline station occupies
the site of 353-349 Spring Street and 303, 304 West Street,
which have been demolished since 1927.
March 6, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same scene four years later. In the background may be
seen the large, white Standard Statistics Building on Hudson
Street, built in 1930, when the rest of the West Street build-
ings, up to Clarkson Street (Pier 40) were demolished.
June 3, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724666f-b.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY
